Upgrading my GitHub Pages blog to Nuxt 3
An overview of my newly upgraded GitHub Pages blog powered by Nuxt 3
My personal website has always lived on GitHub Pages at

. The first version was built with the Jekyll framework. I started learning about Vue, and Nuxt seemed like an interesting alternative to Jekyll that would allow me to practice frontend development. In September 2020 I deployed the first version of the new site using Nuxt 2 and Vue 2.

I recently went through the process of upgrading from Nuxt 2 to Nuxt 3. This upgrade path also included an upgrade from Vue 2 to Vue 3. My previous attempts to upgrade this site from Nuxt 2 to Nuxt 3 failed because of error messages that I couldn't work through. This time, with a big help from AI, I got through the entire upgrade and learned a lot in the process. I'm happy to share my new blog that is powered by Vue 3, Nuxt 3, Nuxt Content v2!
The Nuxt Content module is a powerful git-based CMS. Articles written in Markdown are converted to HTML. My site is prerendered
Here's a comparison of the old and new way of fetching data from Nuxt content.

<script>
export default {
  async asyncData ({ $content, params }) {
    const file = `${params.year}/${params.month}/${params.day}/${params.slug}`
    const article = await $content(file).fetch()
    return { article }
  },
  data () {
    return {
      showComments: false
    }
  }
}
</script>
language-html shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai

<script setup>
const route = useRoute();
const { year, month, day, slug } = route.params;
const page = `/${year}/${month}/${day}/${slug}`;
const { data: article } = await useAsyncData(route.params.slug, () =>
  queryContent(page).findOne()
);
</script>
. I initially misunderstood the statement about this needing to be a unique value and I gave it a value of
, but this caused a strange cache issue when I viewed different articles. The problem didn't show when I was developing with
, it only showed up when I built the site and served in locally with
. Since it is used in a dynamic page
, it needs to have a unique value for every page for the dynamic route.
on the Nuxt 3 site about migration to Nuxt 4:
language-javascript shiki shiki-themes github-light github-dark monokai
// This would be unsafe in a dynamic page (e.g. `[slug].vue`) because the route slug makes a difference
// to the data fetched, but Nuxt can't know that because it's not reflected in the key.
// Instead, you should use a key that uniquely identifies the data fetched.
Wow, there is already a Nuxt 4 in the works! Hopefully the upgrade process from Nuxt 3 to 4 is easier than Nuxt 2 to 3.
yarn clean && yarn generate && yarn serve

It is available in Nuxt 3.9.0 or higher.
Vue 3 allows for a much more streamlined single file component syntax with
. For most of the component I did some minimal cleanup and then asked ChatGPT to convert the component script tag to use the new script setup syntax, and that worked very well!
My blog is update using the following GitHub Action:

name: github pages

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - master
  pull_request:

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Setup Node
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: "20"

      - name: Cache dependencies
        uses: actions/cache@v4
        with:
          path: ~/.npm
          key: ${{ runner.os }}-node-${{ hashFiles('**/package-lock.json') }}
          restore-keys: |
            ${{ runner.os }}-node-

      - run: yarn
      - run: yarn build
      - run: yarn lint
      - run: yarn generate

      - name: deploy
        uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v4
        with:
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          publish_dir: dist

Most of my blog articles only include text and images. In some articles I include dynamic content through iframes to other projects on my GitHub that are deployed on subdomains of
. Another way to add dynamic content it to write Vue components and then embed those directly in the Nuxt Content Markdown files. I wrote
an article about data from YC's Work at a Startup jobs page
and made components that get data from a data store and then render that data using Apex Charts.

Previoulsy I had used Vuex to do this, but I switched to using Pinia which is Vue's new module for managing state. I use LLMs to convert the store module from Vuex to Pinia and also used LLMs to update the components that use the store, and it worked!
Setting up the plugin for Apex Charts looks like this:

This post on my GitHub Pages blog

I added i18n to my site mostly to learn how it works. Nuxt i18n has different strategies for how different locales are displayed. Previously I used a URL prefix for all locales other than the default locale (English). Switching to other locales would switch to
In this upgrade I switched to the
option which instead stores the locale in a cookie. This makes generating my site easier because it does not require generating a locale for each blog tag or blog article.
I currently do not have i18n for the articles on my blog, but I'm hoping to add this in a future update once there is better support for it in Nuxt Content.
